title: Is it a red flag that the man I am dating won't speak to me over an NFL game?
opening_message: I'm feeling really confused and hurt because my boyfriend won't talk to me after his team lost a big game against mine, and I'm wondering if this is just a weird one-time thing or if it's a sign of some bigger issues in our relationship.

all: I'm in a long-distance relationship with someone who's a huge fan of their college team, and we're still getting to know each other.
Despite being rivals, I didn't rub it in when his team lost to mine; I respected him enough not to be a jerk about it.
Now he won't talk to me because of the game result, which feels like an overreaction and makes me feel ridiculous for even bringing it up as an issue.
His behavior is making me question whether this is a red flag in his personality – would he continue to pout and punish others if things didn't go his way?
I'm worried that if we get into a relationship, this kind of behavior would become a problem for me – I want someone who can handle losing graciously.
I feel sad and frustrated because my team's victory is being ruined by his silence; it's like he's punishing me for something that wasn't even my fault.
I'm unsure if I should confront him about how his behavior is affecting me or wait for him to come around when he's "finished licking his wounds".
I'm prone to overthinking things, which is why I brought this question to the collective – seeking feedback and perspective on whether I should be concerned.
I appreciate someone who can laugh at themselves and not take things too seriously; his current behavior feels like a lack of self-awareness.
I want someone who can be a good sport when things don't go their way, but his reaction makes me wonder if that's something he's capable of.

turns.content: I'm feeling really confused and hurt because my boyfriend won't talk to me after his team lost a big game against mine, and I'm wondering if this is just a weird one-time thing or if it's a sign of some bigger issues in our relationship.

It sounds like you're feeling really frustrated and hurt by your boyfriend's silence after the big game. It's understandable that you're wondering if this is just a one-off reaction or if there are deeper issues at play. Can you tell me more about what happened leading up to his team's loss, and how you typically handle conflicts or tough conversations with him?

"Yea, I'm still trying to wrap my head around it. We were both so hyped before the game, and I was actually more nervous than him, which is weird because he's usually the one who's super competitive. But after they lost, he just shut down on me and won't even look at his phone. It feels like a total overreaction, you know? Like, I get that it sucked to lose, but come on, we've had way worse games in our fantasy league and he never acts like this."

It sounds like the intensity of the game was really high for both of you, and then his team's loss just threw everything off kilter. It's like he got totally swept up in the emotions of it all. And yeah, it does seem like an overreaction - especially compared to how you've seen him handle other tough games before. How do you think this silence is affecting your usual dynamic with each other?

"It feels like I'm being penalized for something I didn't do, you know? Like, we're supposed to be a team, and now he's shutting me out because his team lost. It just doesn't seem fair. And it's not even just about winning or losing - it's like... I feel like I'm missing out on something important, some connection with him that usually helps us bounce back from tough losses."

I totally get what you mean by feeling penalized for something you didn't do! It sounds like you're feeling really disconnected and left out right now. You're used to having a strong emotional support system in your relationship, and this silence is making you feel like that's being taken away from you. How are you coping with the sense of disconnection - are you trying to reach out to him or give him space?

"Man, it's like... I'm trying to reach out, but it feels like I'm just talking to myself. Every time I think about bringing it up, I'm worried he'll just shut me down or not want to talk about it. It's weird because we've always been pretty chill about our teams' rivalries before. Like, remember that game when his team lost? I didn't gloat or anything. I figured he'd respect my sportsmanship and we could move on from it... but now it feels like that's just not enough."

It sounds like you're feeling really uncertain and hesitant to bring up the issue because you're worried about how he'll respond. You've always tried to be respectful of his team and your own teams' rivalries, but this time it's feeling like it's not enough. What do you think would happen if you did reach out and try to talk to him about what's going on?

"I don't know, man... I feel like if I reach out and try to talk to him, it'll just get blown out of proportion and things will escalate even more. Maybe I'm just trying to avoid a whole mess, but at the same time, it's like, shouldn't someone be willing to listen when you're trying to resolve something? It feels like I'm stuck in limbo, not knowing what to do or say."

It sounds like you're caught between wanting to talk things through and being worried about making things worse. You're right that it's reasonable to expect someone to be willing to listen when you're trying to resolve an issue. Does it feel like this silence is a bigger deal because it's not just about the game, but also about your relationship and how you connect with each other?

"Exactly. It feels like this silence has taken on a life of its own in my head. The more I think about it, the more I'm convinced that he's avoiding me or doesn't care about what's going on between us. But deep down, I know that's not necessarily true... and that's what's really freaking me out."

It sounds like you're caught in a cycle of worry and doubt, and it's taking a toll on your emotions. It can be tough to quiet the voices in our head, but maybe we can try to find some clarity together. What do you think would happen if you were able to have a calm and honest conversation with him about how this silence is affecting you?

"I don't know, man... I feel like if I were to bring it up with him, he'd just get defensive and try to shift the blame. It's like, I get that we all have our own flaws, but when someone consistently reacts like this, it makes me wonder if they're capable of growth or change. I don't want to assume the worst, but at the same time, I don't want to be stuck in a situation where I'm constantly walking on eggshells."

It sounds like you're feeling frustrated and unsure about how to move forward. You're right that having an honest conversation can be tough when it feels like the other person might get defensive. Have you ever had a moment where he showed growth or change in response to your concerns? Even if it was small, what did that look like for you, and could that give you some hope for moving forward?

"Honestly, it's hard for me to think of a specific moment where he showed growth or change in response to my concerns. Usually, when I bring up issues, he just gets defensive and we move on. But if I'm being real with myself, there was this one time where we were playing a game and I lost badly... he laughed it off and told me 'good game' even though I was really upset about losing. It wasn't a huge moment or anything, but it felt like maybe, just maybe, he could understand when things didn't go my way."

It sounds like that small moment of understanding might have been a tiny crack in his defensive armor. Even if it's not a big deal to him, it seems like it meant something to you. What do you think would happen if you were to build on that small moment and try to have an open conversation with him about how this silence is affecting you?

"I don't know, man... it's like, if I bring it up, he might just brush me off or get defensive again. But a part of me wishes he could see that this isn't just about some silly joke or misunderstanding - it feels like a bigger deal to me because it's affecting our dynamic and making me feel unheard. I guess what I'm hoping is that if we can have an open conversation, maybe he'll start to realize how his actions are impacting others too."
